text: starting model, think trying . happens HW model? example, consider population mussels reproduce broadcast spawning: year, individuals release gametes water column, meet gametes random undergo syngamy form new zygote (see figure). life cycle New Zealand green-lipped mussel (Perna canaliculus, kütai). larvae, green-lipped mussels free-swimming. metamorphose settle onto seaweed subsequently onto solid surfaces. nature, many mussels iteroparous (spawning one reproductive episode lifetimes) sake simple model, ’re going assume semelparous (reproduce die) individual population produces gametes (via meiosis), spews water column, dies (modeling annuals, discrete non-overlapping generations). gametes fuse diploid zygotes (probabilistically, random), spend time planktonic larva, settle hard surface grow adult mussels. next year, adult mussels spew gametes water die, etc (circle life…). model, number Adults represents total population size (N). ’s life stage tracking one generation next. ’re also going model simplest base case, one locus two alleles. three genotypes, like 3 different kinds Adult mussels, represented separate stock box. mussels genotype produce gametes (every individual produces number gametes, selection!). gametes joined random (following binomial probabilities) form next generation adults. generation, want examine observed genotype frequencies (based stocks), allele frequencies (calculated observed geno frequencies), HW expected genotype frequencies (calculated allele frequencies). create new generation mussels, following HW expectations, using allele frequencies gametes determine many zygotes genotype formed. Note ’re going assume population size affected ’s large, ’ll use N = 10000 total population example. ’re examining HW, occurs quickly, ’ll use just 10 time steps (generations).

Note mean population always remain HW proportions, even though allele frequencies changing generation! good demonstration fact nonrandom mating thing puts population HW proportions. evolutionary forces, must examine change allele frequency across generations detect effects.

(p0 * p0 * N) genotypeA1A2, use equation N - genoA1A1 - genoA2A2. ensures end right number total individuals, N. numbers genotype stocks, can set equations freq11, freq12 freq22. mainly want variables ease graphing manipulation calculations. equations variables ? Example: freq11’s equation geno11 / N Now variable greatest interest: p! calculate frequency allele using genotype frequencies? aren’t sure, check Angie. can also check key end though ’s best can try work . variables related drift (driftSD, seed, drift, toggledrift p adj), equations somewhat complicated ’ll learn little work enter model. Also see table quick reference. driftSD standard deviation amount change due drift. Since change due drift random, positive value negative value know amount change depends population size. small population, large change likely occur large population. can control factor variable driftSD. ’re using equation binomial variance , see likely small versus large changes depends current allele frequency population size. square root part occurs standard deviation square root variance. equation : SQRT( (p * (1 - p) ) / (2 * N) ) toggledrift variable use turn drift tell Vensim create new simulation run drift (use seed equation drift). useful know happen drift occurring also allow us check model set correctly. also help us run multiple replicate runs drift can act differently – different value toggledrift correspond different random outcome model. value toggledrift = 0 special though, use run model randomness . encode ability put equation p adj, ’ll shortly. ’s equation values use:  drift variable ’ll use figure (randomly) much p changes chance, calculated anew generation. just set standard deviation (SD) distribution, now use function (RANDOM NORMAL) choose value distribution. Change equally likely increase decrease, ’ll use mean zero. function, also specify minimum maximum ’ll use -1 1 since allele frequency can’t possibly larger smaller ! function requires arguments following order RANDOM NORMAL(min, max, mean, sd, seed) equation RANDOM NORMAL(-2, 2, 0, driftSD, toggledrift) ’re finally ready complicated equation , one adjusting allele frequency effect drift, p adj (p-adjust). variable, since want turn drift , need use statement – drift ’s . also need make sure add together p drift, don’t get value less zero greater 1. , just want value 0 1, since ’s impossible reality exceed limits. function Vensim need ELSE( cond , ontrue , onfalse ). can see requires 3 arguments (condition, ’s true, ’s false). actually 3 conditions meet ’re going complicated nested --else statement. ’s equation ’ll provide text explanation . ELSE(toggledrift=0, p , ELSE( (p+drift) >= 1.0 , 1 , ELSE( (p+drift)<=0 , 0 , p+drift ) ) ) can see three --else functions. Reading left right, statement says toggledrift set 0, make p adj p (happens drift). ELSE part says, (p + drift) greater equal 1.0, make p adj equal 1.0 (ensures don’t 100% A1 alleles, impossible). second ELSE says (p + drift) less equal zero, set p adj 0 (preventing us negative numbers alleles). Finally, last ELSE says none preceding things true (thus, p + drift 0 1), set p adj equal (p + drift). Ok, hardest part. left equations deltaA1A1, deltaA1A2, deltaA2A2. causing drift happen allele frequency directly, equations similar used last week HW model, just using p adj instead p. , deltaA1A1, get: deltaA1A1 equation : (N * p adj * p adj) - genoA1A1 Go ahead set equations deltaA1A2 deltaA2A2 well. finished entering equations, check make sure correct (may want use key end). ready click Simulate run model. get graph, select three genotype stocks (whatever variable want) click Graph. code: Note that for the drift model, we are primarily interested in what happens to the allele frequency, p, over time. So instead of graphing genotype frequencies, we want to graph allele frequency. We could also graph heterozygosity, as that's our common estimate of genetic variation.

what: Genotype fitness and mean population fitness
title: BIOL 322 Lab 4. Selection
text: Create following four variables place arrows indicated: Set equations fitness variable: Set equation **** : wmean = (wA1A1*p adj*p adj) + (wA1A2*2*p adj*(1-p adj) ) + (wA2A2*(1-p adj)*(1-p adj) )

previous_headings: Add Selection to the Drift Model
title: BIOL 322 Lab 4. Selection
text: Update flows selection occurs newly formed zygotes: deltaA1A1 = (N * p adj * p adj * wA1A1 / wmean) - genoA1A1 deltaA1A2 = (N * 2 * p adj * (1 - p adj) * wA1A2 / wmean) - genoA1A2 deltaA2A2 = (N * (1 - p adj) * (1 - p adj) * wA2A2 / wmean) - genoA2A2

title: BIOL 322 Lab 5. Gene Flow
text: Today, ’re ready add gene flow model, alongside selection drift. completing today’s model, ’ll creation allows us investigate effects three major forces evolutionary change can observe human timescale! real world, might often thinking gene flow occurring individuals migrate one sub-population another. simplicity, ’ll focus single sub-population consider migration “continent” influences . island-continent model, continent allele frequency gene flow equilibrium. adjust allele frequency gametes applying drift, selection occur viability zygotes (survival maturity). need add two variables: \(p_m\): frequency allele \(A_1\) continent population (range 0-1). \(m\): rate migration proportion (range 0-1). equation allele frequency next generation : \(p_{t+1} = (1 - m) \times p_t + m \times p_m\) ’s reference image completed model:

what: Add Gene Flow to the Model
title: BIOL 322 Lab 5. Gene Flow
text: Create two variables , set follows: Update equation p include gene flow: p = (freqA1A1 + 0.5*freqA1A2) * (1-m) + pm*m
